Is it worth preserving the function `tvm.target.rasp()` which just redirects to `tvm.target.arm_cpu('rasp3b')`? There's a bunch of tutorial/discuss/stackoverflow code that mentions it, and it seems like an easy way to not break existing out-of-tree code?

Thanks for raising this question, please use https://discuss.tvm.ai/ for general discussion. This might have something specific to the TX2 board env (related to the implementation of RTLD.local, in theory, nnvm should resolve to its internal version of the json), as such a problem does not occur in normal desktops. I also recall @kazum have some related fix on such symbolic resolve issues 

As a temporary workaround, you could try to use tvm from a desktop and use cross compilation and ship through RPC.

```[Task  1/19]  Current/Best:    0.00/   0.00 GFLOPS | Progress: (201/1000) | 499.30 s Done```
The result is 0.00 / 0.00. Didn't your doc sync with your code? Or some place I omit?

@kevinthesun

@kaishijeng Yes. L2Normlization is required for gluoncv ssd implementation: https://github.com/dmlc/gluon-cv/blob/master/gluoncv/model_zoo/ssd/ssd.py I plan to support deploying these models in the next few weeks.

- Renamed `np_forward` to `forward`, same for `backward`, and now it is possible to pass additional
  parameters to these functions via `additional_params`.
- Added support for multiple inputs.
- Now additional parameters to the numgrad checking function are passed as a single dictionary.

- I'm not sure yet about merging the behaviour of `numerical_grads=True` and
  `numerical_grads='if_possible'`, so I left it as it is for now.
- Require passing `numerical_grads=True` explicitly if no reference function is specified.
- Got rid of explicit passing of input variables in most of the tests. Also shapes cannot be
  passed with `grad_input_vars` now.

Also added some tests for `check_function` itself.

The main thing that is left to do is something like a tutorial on what to do if numerical gradient
testing fails. I'll return to this task in a few days.

Tried test out a simple RNN *.onnx model exported from PyTorch which makes use of Gather() and noticed in the `OnnxOpConverter` that the `attr` dictionary is empty; causing errors.

Happy to provide the *.onnx model if requested, though for now here's a screenshot of relevant parts of the model containing the arguments passed to the Gather() opereator.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8392982/43608308-63ba1ece-96d3-11e8-94c1-e143e7da60ad.png)
@tqchen , even if it is not a bug, the comment looks pretty confusing

As far as i can tell, the ndk is switched off by default. so the original code is correct. You will need to pass use_ndk=True to the measure_option. 

Maybe you can followup on specific problems you encountered when tuning android on the https://discuss.tvm.ai/ and we can help improve this process together

Thanks for your comment.

For this problem, if kwargs.get('use_ndk', False), which means ndk should not be invoked, in the following line we should not call ndk.create_shared. That’s why I maintain that the original code is incorrect. I found this problem from receiving error message like load_module_tar func is not found.
You will need to pass in build_func="ndk" in your measure option, which will automatically set use_ndk to be True in kwargs

see also NOTE in https://docs.tvm.ai/tutorials/autotvm/tune_nnvm_arm.html#set-tuning-options

@merrymercy maybe it makes sense to update the tutorial to pass in build_func and measure_func as keyword arguments by default
Yes, my point is that ndk.create_shared is only allowed to be called when use_ndk=True, while the original code calls ndk.created_shared when use_ndk=False

To be clear, kwargs is a dict, and kwargs.get("use_ndk", False) will return the value inside the dict if it is available, if not, it will return False. 

- So if user pass in the ```default_build_func(..., use_ndk=xxx)```, xxx will be used

- If user does not pass in use_ndk, then the default is False
```python
default_build_func(...)
```

That is, kwargs.get("use_ndk", False) is not equivalent to `kwargs["use_ndk"]== False`, rather it is 

```python
 kwargs["use_ndk"] if "use_ndk" in kwargs else False
```

1. Unstable issue
    What's your phone? What's is unstable?
    You should turn on 'Keep RPC Alive' on the APP. On my pixel2 phone, although the android system reports the app is crashed, the app just works well. You can see whether the tuning looks like normal.

2. The code is correct. If you set `build_func='ndk'` in the option, then `kwargs = {"use_ndk": True}`. Otherwise it does not contain the key "use_ndk", so `kwargs.get("use_ndk", False)` is False.

3. You can report your unstable error by enabling log. 
Put these lines in the beginning of your script
```python
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
```
remove the progress_bar callback function in

```python
        # do tuning
        tuner_obj.tune(n_trial=min(n_trial, len(tsk.config_space)),
                       early_stopping=early_stopping,
                       measure_option=measure_option,
                       callbacks=[
                           # autotvm.callback.progress_bar(n_trial, prefix=prefix),  #### REMOVE THIS LINE
                           autotvm.callback.log_to_file(tmp_log_file)])
```
Then run the script again, it will print every tuning result to the screen.

+1 in the sense of Fusing is target independent and Lowering not. Separation allow flexibility to add target specific implementations after Fusing.
This is a reasonable decision to make. We can roll out something in this direction around next release cycle
Thanks, I will create a PR that add this feature.

@iwasaki-kenta welcome to contribute PR for ```ConstantFill```.

As of now I think we don't have a tutorial about how to develop a new operator across TVM & NNVM.
[TOPI Intro](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/cca57ae6d5815699206da6dfe44b31110edf5ceb/tutorials/topi/intro_topi.py) is a tutorial we have about how to use tvm topi. Community is always there to help with areas which are not documented till now.

The practice till now is for a new frontend operator is to for existing operators from NNVM and wrap it (if there is one).
Or 
Implement a new operator which fits for most of the other frameworks and then wrap it in frontend.

For ```ConstantFill``` it can be wrapped around ```full``` and ```full_like```.

One limitation I would see for ```ConstantFill``` is with ```input_as_shape=true``` and input tensor not being a param. You could asset this case and leave it as a limitation for now.

```tvm/src/runtime/./graph/graph_runtime.cc:577: Check failed: pf != nullptr no such function in module: fuse_conv2d_broadcast_mul_broadcast_add_relu
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'dmlc::Error'

```

Is it ok if I do it like this??

@qingyuanxingsi 

for target=llvm ```lib.get_source()```  and for non targets ```lib.imported_modules[0].get_source()``` can give the llvm source. you may need additional setup to compile on your environment.

I have checked bazel with below changes and the object embeds into the final binary very well.

Add an additional target deploy_resnet18 to pack the nnvm system lib object into library and make deploy_resnet18 dependency for cpp_deploy as shown below. 

Note ```alwayslink=1``` is the trick which enforce embedding this lib completely in final binary even though there is no symbol dependency.

```bash
cc_library(
    name = "deploy_resnet18",
    srcs = ["deploy_resnet18.o"],
    alwayslink=1
)

cc_binary(
    name = "cpp_deploy",
    srcs = ["cpp_deploy.cc"],
    deps = [
        ":tvm_runtime", ":deploy_resnet18"
    ],
)
```

Hope this helps.

@qingyuanxingsi  
about time we are trying options together :)  and you are very close.

I too tried archive of object but that doesn't work alone as the cpp_deploy doesn't refer any symbol directly.
As described above embed the archive rule into the BUILD with ```alwayslink=1``` and try.

@srkreddy1238 Have you tried running the app, can you get correct prediction result?
If so, I will give it another try next week. (**The build system we use is a little different from bazel, we may need certain adjustment**) Much thanks for your instructions so far!!!

I checked upto the symbols of system object in the final binary. Beyond this there shouldn't be any problems.

Pls try and let me know. I will add a section for bazel.

@qingyuanxingsi  

I did a quick check by adding all objects to a bazel build and it work perfectly fine.

```bash
cc_library(
    name = "test_addone_sys",
    srcs = ["test_addone_sys.o"],
    alwayslink=1
)

cc_library(
    name = "tvm_runtime",
    srcs = ["libtvm_runtime_pack.o"],
)

cc_binary(
    name = "bazel_deploy",
    srcs = ["cpp_deploy.o"],
    deps = [
        ":tvm_runtime", ":test_addone_sys"
    ],
    linkopts = [ "-lpthread -ldl" ]
)
```

Suggest to wait a while until #1505 is merged.

sorry I chose the wrong branch, close it.

the root cause is because we static link dmlc-core to tvm shared lib, but on windows, by default the shared library won't expose the symbols (Need annotation like TVM_EXPORTS ). dmlc::Registry::Get is not exposed in this case.

I am currently fix it by re-enable the registry in nnvmcompiler shared lib, but a better fix may be from dmlc-core side to expose this symbol. Any suggestion from tvm team?

@masahi  & @zhreshold welcome to review.

I made some simple comments, but the wrapping is still a bit raw(it reads more like C rather than Go), here is what we want ideally(note I am not expert in Go, so syntax might be wrong)

```go
mod = gotvm.LoadFromFile("/path/to/mymodule.so")
f1 = mod.GetFunction("myfunction")
# need to debate how to support function invocation, either in normal style or java style
f1.invoke(args) 

myarr = gotvm.empty(shape, ctx);
```

Actually since, this involves API design discussion, can you please open an RFC issue so that more people can participate? Maybe there are good ideas from the community, I am not expert in Go, so I can only generalize from my experience in other languages

OK, maybe we need to add a bit more additional details of device-related build into the doc. See the code here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/module.py#L93

What is happening for CUDA like modules is that we need to generate two files
- myfunc.o (the host module you can obtain by mod.save)
- device_blob.cc (the device part binary file that contains the device side binary embedded in C++)

What is happening in x.export_library("xx.so") is that we will call ```_PackImportsToC``` to create devc.cc, and then combine this together with the .o file. 

See also the implementation of PackImportsToC https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/codegen/codegen.cc#L33

I know it is a bit twisted, but this is a good hack to actually implement the device linking strategy and embed the binary blob into the final object file. It might make sense to provide an example for CUDA build and add a specific document to explain tvm runtime module export and the relation of the files.

Looking into these implementation, and document them will be very helpful for the community
